awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: A Multi-Layer Learning Approach to Mobile Traffic Filtering
awd_abstract_narration:
The mobile ecosystem has become an attractive target for various types of abuses. For instance, many mobile applications leak sensitive user information, such as email addresses and location, which is a privacy issue. Second, attackers routinely disguise malware in seemingly legitimate mobile apps to launch attacks, which poses security threats. Third, many mobile apps and sites push intrusive und undesirable ads, such as auto-play and pop-ups, which harm usability. The objective of this project is to defend against these abuses in the mobile ecosystem through real-time on-device filtering of network traffic on a mobile device.

The project performs multi-layer network traffic analysis with help of machine learning. It extracts features and trains learning models to produce filtering rules, which can be applied on the device. Filtering on the mobile device is particularly challenging due to limited resources, lack of visibility into packet payload, and potential collateral damage on the affected apps. The filtering approach used is envisioned as universal (i.e., applicable across all apps), automated (compared to the current practice of manually maintained privacy related data), adaptive (to the ever-changing threats), and user-centric (i.e., customized per user) while leveraging collaboration among users. The general framework will be validate in three case studies against the following abuse scenarios in the mobile ecosystem: (i) intrusive ads (ii) privacy leaks (iii) malvertising. This project is excepted to enhance the usability, privacy, and security of the mobile ecosystem and will inform policies and practices on mobile data transparency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop techniques for filtering advertising, tracking, and other unwanted traffic. At the core of the project lies the need to create rules that can filter and block network traffic. One representative highlight of this project is AutoFR ("Automated Filter Rule Generation), which addresses an important special case: creating filter rules for blocking advertising on browsers, a.k.a. adblocking. 

Adblocking relies on filter lists, which are manually curated and maintained by a community of expert filter list authors. Filter list curation is a laborious process that does not scale well to a large number of sites or over time. In  AutoFR, we introduced a reinforcement learning framework to fully automate the process of filter rule creation and evaluation for sites of interest. We designed an algorithm based on multi-arm bandits to generate filter rules that block ads while controlling the trade-off between blocking ads and avoiding visual breakage of the webpage. We tested AutoFR on thousands of sites and we showed that it is efficient: it takes only a few minutes to generate filter rules for a site of interest. We also showed that AutoFR is effective: it generates filter rules that can block 86% of the ads, as compared to 87% by EasyList, while achieving comparable visual breakage. Furthermore, we found that AutoFR generates filter rules that generalize well to new sites. 

AutoFR appears in USENIX Security 2023. The code and datasets are made publicly available. We envision that AutoFR can assist the adblocking community to automate filter rule generation at scale, not only for URL-based adblocking on browsers but also for other purposes (e.g., to block tracking), other types of filter rules (e.g., based on element hiding), and other platforms (such as mobile, smart TVs, and VR devices).


Last Modified: 03/21/2023
Modified by: Athina Markopoulou

Image
  • AutoFR automates the steps taken by human experts to generate filter rules that block advertising.
    Hieu Le
    Copyrighted
    Athina Markopoulou
    AutoFR Overview
